column5: Multiracial identity development: Developmental correlates and themes among multiracial adults.
column13: Adams, Jessica Lyn: The Ohio State U, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.58(5-B), Nov 1997, pp. 2662.
column20: This study examined some of the common experiences that have been theorized to characterize the racial/ethnic identity development of multiracial individuals. The construct of ethnic identity was examined along with factors identified in the literature as influencing racial/ethnic identity development such as family support of multiracial heritage, sense of belonging, coping with discrimination, and racial/ethnic legitimacy testing. An attempt was also made to explore how ethnic identity and other factors such as self-esteem, racial diversity of the community in which one was raised, and choice of self-label are related. Seventy-three multiracial adults completed measures that assessed ethnic identity, self-esteem, racial/ethnic legitimacy testing experiences, family support of multiracial heritage and coping. Results indicated that a majority of participants had experienced racial/ethnic legitimacy testing from those racial groups which were part of their racial/ethnic heritage. While self-esteem was not found to be related to racial/ethnic legitimacy testing as predicted, statistically significant relationships were obtained between self-esteem and ethnic identity, and self-esteem and family support of multiraciality. Family support of multiraciality and racial diversity of neighborhood in which individual was raised were found to be significant predictors of ethnic identity. This finding is consistent with existing literature which has identified these two factors as having a positive impact on racial identity resolution. Participants were asked to identify a stressful situation in which they felt rejected due to some aspect of their multiracial heritage. A component of ethnic identity labeled ethnic identity achievement was found to be related to coping strategies that involved attempts to either alter this stressful situation or create some positive meaning from it. No significant predictors of choice of monoracial or multiracial self-label were identified. Methodological limitations of some of the measures, as well as the small sample size, were identified as reasons for interpreting these findings with caution. Further research using improved measures to assess the constructs of interest was recommended. Implications for counseling were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column20: Racial attitudes of 60 preschool children (aged 3-6 yrs; 28 boys, 32 girls) from either a monoracial Euro-American child-care program (n = 16), a monoracial African-American program (n = 12), or a multiracial program (25 Euro-Americans, 7 African-Americans) were assessed using the Preschool Racial Attitudes Measure II. Despite the overall neutral attitudes reflected by these children, evidence of a Euro-American bias among older children (aged >4.5 yrs) was found. Replication with a large, randomly selected sample is desirable. Recognizing and understanding early racial attitudes may be a key factor in fostering positive racial identity and preventing the formation of prejudice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Friendship patterns and peer relations of biracial girls.
column13: Fields, Rachel Hannah: California School of Professional Psychology - Berkeley/alameda, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(6-B), Dec 1996, pp. 4054.
column20: The prevalence of biracial children has dramatically increased in recent years, yet little is known about their normal development. Developing an understanding of the perception of friendships and peer relationships held by biracial children is particularly important given that social relationships may be more complicated for them than for monoracial children. Participants in this study were girls between the ages of 8 and 11. This study compared the friendship and peer relationship perceptions of monoracial (African American) and biracial African American-Caucasian girls. Participants (N = 25) were interviewed using the Cornell Interview of Peer and Friends (CIPF). Their mothers filled out a short racial identity/demographics questionnaire. It was hypothesized that biracial girls face a more complex developmental process than monoracial girls, and thus more difficulties in the areas of friendship and peer relationships. The quantitative analysis found no differences between monoracial and biracial girls on CIPF overall scores. Biracial girls received higher scores on the subscale Developmental Appropriateness, indicating more maturity in this area. In addition, biracial girls reported a more stable experience of themselves with all friends and more general satisfaction with their friendships than did monoracial girls. Other differences were found between participants classified as higher income versus those classified as lower income. Higher income participants received healthier overall scores on the CIPF. They also indicated that it was easier to get children to play with them and they had less negative interactions with their peers. A qualitative analysis revealed a thoughtful and insightful understanding of friendship for both monoracial and biracial girls. Participant mothers also gave cogent accounts of addressing race related issues with their daughters. Results indicated a similar developmental pattern for monoracial and biracial girls and suggested that bi (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Jones, Rosanna Marie: California School of Professional Psychology - San Diego, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(6-B), Dec 1995, pp. 3448.
column20: This study examined whether biracial (Black/White) male children as compared to Black and White male children, showed an egalitarian perspective in the discipline ratings given to mischievous protagonists in a story, who varied in race. This was based on the rationale that biracial children's perceptions of Whites and Blacks are based on a racial continuum rather than categories. Because biracial children have a dual heritage, they may not categorize people in terms of discrete categories based on appearance. If this is the case, biracial children would consider other aspects of the person, such as their social behavior, to be more important than race. It was hypothesized that biracial children would not be influenced by the race of a mischievous protagonist in making discipline judgments. Monoracial White and Black children were expected to weigh race more heavily in evaluating the behaviors of cross-race children. This study also analyzed children's moral judgments to see whether there was a significant difference as a function of the level of damage caused by the protagonist in hypothetical situations involving intentional aggression. Subjects were also predicted to decrease their initial discipline rating after they were given extenuating information about the protagonist. Seventy-two biracial male children, 72 White male children and 55 Black male children were randomly assigned to see pictures of and hear stories about a White, Black or no race protagonist. Each subject responded to stories depicting both high and low damage outcomes. After each story, they indicated how much discipline the protagonist deserved, heard the extenuating information, and again gave a discipline rating. There were no significant differences in the ratings of high and low damage information. Discipline ratings decreased significantly after extenuating information was given for all subjects. Black subjects gave higher discipline ratings to White protagonists than to Black protagoni (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Biracial identity development and alienation in racially mixed adults.
column13: Aikins, Antonia Louise: California School of Professional Psychology - Los Angeles, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.56(5-B), Nov 1995, pp. 2851.
column20: The Biracial Identity Development Inventory (BIDI) was developed and quantitatively examined to look at the dimensions of biracial identity development. Exploration into the empirical relationship between stages of biracial identity development and perceived alienation was investigated in a sample of 83 biracial (African-American/Caucasian) adults living in Southern California. Subjects were recruited from local and college newspapers. Subjects had the option of completing a questionnaire through the mail or by telephone. The development of the BIDI consisted of establishing a theoretical base and item pool, having experts rate the items, administering the scale, and running statistical analyses. The five subscales included: Lack of Salience, Conflict, Monoracial Identification, Appreciation, and Interaction. Lack of Salience and Conflict exhibited "respectable" internal-consistency reliability scores. A non-experimental method with a correlational and cross-sectional design was utilized. Alienation included the constructs Normlessness, Powerlessness, and Social Isolation. The investigator hypothesized that people at different levels of the biracial identity development stages would differ in Normlessness, Powerlessness, and Social Isolation scores and that the biracial identity subscales would account for a significant portion of the explained variance in Alienation. Results suggest that biracial adults who are high vs. low on the Conflict and Monoracial Identification subscales of biracial identity significantly varied in the degrees of Alienation experienced. Subjects with higher Conflict scores had higher Powerlessness scores, while subjects with higher Monoracial Identification scores had higher Social Isolation scores. However, the low reliability on the Monoracial Identification subscale indicates that these results need to be interpreted cautiously. Appreciation approached significance with individuals higher in Appreciation experiencing less Social Isolatio (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial categorization of multiracial children in the schools.
column13: Chiong, Jane Ayers: U Massachusetts, US
column14: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(3-A), Sep 1995, pp. 0806.
column20: Multiracial children, who are the offspring of multiple racial unions, have unique needs which are possibly not being met in the schools because, among other things, they are racially categorized on the basis of "one race only" on school forms. This monoracial categorization has become a visible symbol that acts as a foundation for a much wider array of experiences and situations in our schools and communities which affect the racial self-image of multiracial children. This incomplete categorization affects awareness and funding for supportive measures which should be available to them. The basic question which this dissertation raises is the question of whether the needs of interracial children are being met in the schools. In order to study this question, the school's racial categorization procedures as predominant cultural forms were investigated by way of its instruments--school forms, curriculum, resources, cultural programming and school material culture. In order to answer these questions, this inquiry utilized predominantly two methods of data collection: (1) documentation analysis of government and school forms and (2) semi-structured interviews with teachers as key informants. To establish a focus for the direction of the research, a theory of radical pedagogy was used to critically analyze the role of the schools in fostering or obstructing a more positive racial identity in interracial children and a theory of classification to provide a framework to analyze both the nature and language of our racial categorization procedures and its' instruments in the schools. This dissertation found that the schools do unknowingly make the normal racial identity development process problematic for at least some of those students who might want to select more than one racial identity. Multiracial children's invisibility in the schools' racial categorization procedures mirrors a wider range of their invisibility in school curriculum, books, cultural programs, class (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Beyond Black and/or White: A New Paradigm for Multiracial People. [References].
column13: Huang, Larke Nahme: American University, Washington, DC, US
column14: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.38(3), Mar,  1993
column20: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1993, Vol 38(3), 306-307. Reviews the book, Racially Mixed People in America by Maria P. P. Root (Ed.) (see record 1992-97305-000). In this edited volume, Root presents a new paradigm for the emerging multiracial population in America. The call for deconstruction of existing theory and the creation of new paradigms for understanding and investigating the multicultural experience is a major premise of this book. Existing social, political, and theoretical frameworks--based on monocultural, monoracial, linear models of social relations and social identity--have forced biracial individuals to choose one or the other culture and to deny significant parts of their heritage and existence. These models mirror the dichotomous, forced choice schemes of racial classification. This volume seeks to correct these practices and perceptions by presenting alternative approaches to social identity and racial classification based on the incorporation of simultaneous membership and multiple, fluid identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial preferences and identifications of White elementary schoolchildren.
column13: Friedman, Philip: Howard U
column14: Contemporary Educational Psychology. Vol.5(3), Jul 1980, pp. 256-265.
column20: Examined the racial preferences and identifications of White children in both a White monoracial and a multiracial setting. A doll selection procedure originally described by K. B. Clark and M. K. Clark (1939, 1947) to study racial awareness and preferences in Black children was employed with 120 kindergarten, 1st-, and 3rd-grade children. Most Ss showed a marked preference for White over comparable Black dolls. However, more Black doll selections were made in multiracial than in monoracial schools, particularly among male Ss. White doll color preference also significantly decreased at the 3rd-grade level. This finding was consistently observed in response to each racial preference question. Neither race of the interviewer nor sex of the child had a significant effect on doll color preferences. Few errors were made in response to a series of 5 racial identification questions. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: An analysis of upper elementary Afro-, Anglo-, and Mexican-American students' attitudes toward race related concepts.
column10:
Baptiste, H. Prentice

Baptiste, Mira L

Miott, Roosevelt O
column13: Baptiste, H. Prentice: U Houston
column14: Journal of Research & Development in Education. Vol.11(1), Fal 1977, pp. 46-51.
column20: Examined variations in attitudes toward race-related concepts among Black, White, and Mexican-American children in 4 urban schools representing both multiracial and monoracial environments. Ss were 392 3rd-6th graders 7-22 yrs old, 57% males and 43% females, and almost equally divided into 3 academic achievement levels. The investigators designed the MRP-Selected Race Related Concepts Instrument, utilizing the semantic differential model so that each of 6 concepts was evaluated by a set of bipolar adjective pairs. Based on the percentage of positive and negative responses, for all concepts except "Spanish," positive responses were significant. Ss gave preference to concepts related to their own group and displayed negativism toward each other. With the exception of Mexican-Americans, Ss in monoracial schools were more positive toward their own group. Results imply that racially mixed schools do not necessarily promote positive racial attitudes, nor do monoracial schools necessarily promote negative attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column14: Proceedings of the Annual Convention of the American Psychological Association.  1973, pp. 223-224.
column20: Administered the Clark and Clark Doll Test (1939) to 240 schoolchildren to examine children's racial awareness and preference. The effects of several independent variables were examined: school type (monoracial and multiracial); grade level (kindergarten, third and fifth grade); sex of child; and race of tester (black and white). Black Ss preferred black dolls to white dolls and white Ss preferred white dolls to black dolls. However, white Ss in multiracial schools preferred white dolls significantly less than white Ss in monoracial schools. Results are interpreted as an indication that the "black is beautiful" movement has facilitated positive self-identity among black children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
